aria-hidden="true"><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/jeffrey-gettleman" class="css-uwwqev"><img alt="Jeffrey Gettleman" title="Jeffrey Gettleman" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2018/10/10/multimedia/author-jeffrey-gettleman/author-jeffrey-gettleman-thumbLarge-v3.png" class="css-dc6zx6 ey68jwv2"/></a><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/emily-schmall" class="css-uwwqev"><img alt="Emily Schmall" title="Emily Schmall" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/01/07/reader-center/author-emily-schmall/author-emily-schmall-thumbLarge-v2.png" class="css-dc6zx6 ey68jwv2"/></a><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/suhasini-raj" class="css-uwwqev"><img alt="Suhasini Raj" title="Suhasini Raj" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2019/11/22/reader-center/author-Suhasini-Raj/author-Suhasini-Raj-thumbLarge.png" class="css-dc6zx6 ey68jwv2"/></a><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/hari-kumar" class="css-uwwqev"><img alt="Hari Kumar" title="Hari Kumar" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2019/12/13/reader-center/author-hari-kumar/author-hari-kumar-thumbLarge.png" class="css-dc6zx6 ey68jwv2"/></a></div><div class="css-233int epjyd6m0"><p class="css-4anu6l e1jsehar1"><span class="byline-prefix">By </span><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/jeffrey-gettleman" class="css-m3qogn e1jsehar0" itemProp="name">Jeffrey Gettleman</a><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/emily-schmall" class="css-m3qogn e1jsehar0" itemProp="name">Emily Schmall</a><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/suhasini-raj" class="css-ojhyzr e1jsehar0" itemProp="name">Suhasini Raj</a> and <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/hari-kumar" class="last-byline css-ojhyzr e1jsehar0" itemProp="name">Hari Kumar</a></p></div></div><ul class="css-1cgskve epjyd6m3"><li class="css-ccw2r3 epjyd6m2"><time dateTime="2021-06-28T10:24:54-04:00" class="css-qr5h11 e16638kd2"><span class="css-1sbuyqj e16638kd3">June 28, 2021</span></time></li></ul></div></div></div><section name="articleBody" class="meteredContent css-1r7ky0e"><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-0"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">NEW DELHI — At 9:45 p.m., alarms blared across the intensive care unit of Jaipur Golden Hospital. Over two dozen patients on ventilators couldn’t breathe. Some flailed their arms and legs. Others cried for help, choking sounds coming from their throats as if they were being strangled.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Mechanics sprinted to the maintenance room to see what was wrong. Nurses grabbed small plastic pumps to fill the lungs of critically ill patients by hand.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">It wasn’t enough. Jaipur Golden, a respected hospital in Delhi, had run out of medical oxygen. Over the next seven hours, 21 coronavirus patients died.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“Nobody can forget that night,” said Shaista Nigar, the hospital’s nursing superintendent. “It was a total breakdown.”</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="Dropzone-1"></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-1"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Across India, amid <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2021/world/india-covid-cases.html" title="">a devastating second wave</a> of Covid-19, hospitals ran out of beds and <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/05/16/world/asia/india-covid19-black-market.html" title="">critical supplies</a>, contributing to the deaths of untold thousands of people and worsening an already tragic outbreak. By one count, <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/04/23/world/asia/india-covid-oxygen-hospitals.html" title="">oxygen shortages alone</a> have killed <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://projects.datameet.org/covid19/oxygen_shortage_deaths/" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">at least 600 people</a> over the past two months.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">India’s leaders knew the country was vulnerable. Yet <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/05/01/world/asia/india-covid19-modi.html" title="">Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s government</a> and local officials alike failed to prepare for the second wave, according to interviews and a review of government documents by The New York Times.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="ImageBlock-3"><div data-testid="imageblock-wrapper"><figure class="img-sz-large css-hxpw2c e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0" data-testid="photoviewer-children-figure"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><picture><source media="(max-width: 599px) and (min-device-pixel-ratio: 3),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 3dppx),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 288dpi)" srcSet="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/06/22/world/00virus-india-oxygen2/00virus-india-oxygen2-mobileMasterAt3x.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp&disable=upscale&width=1800"/><source media="(max-width: 599px) and (min-device-pixel-ratio: 2),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 2dppx),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 192dpi)" srcSet="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/06/22/world/00virus-india-oxygen2/00virus-india-oxygen2-mobileMasterAt3x.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp&disable=upscale&width=1200"/><source media="(max-width: 599px) and (min-device-pixel-ratio: 1),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 1dppx),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 96dpi)" srcSet="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/06/22/world/00virus-india-oxygen2/00virus-india-oxygen2-mobileMasterAt3x.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp&disable=upscale&width=600"/><img alt="" class="css-r3fift" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/06/22/world/00virus-india-oxygen2/00virus-india-oxygen2-articleLarge.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp&disable=upscale" srcSet="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/06/22/world/00virus-india-oxygen2/00virus-india-oxygen2-articleLarge.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp 600w,https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/06/22/world/00virus-india-oxygen2/00virus-india-oxygen2-jumbo.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp 1024w,https://static01.nyt.com/images/2021/06/22/world/00virus-india-oxygen2/00virus-india-oxygen2-superJumbo.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp 2048w" sizes="((min-width: 600px) and (max-width: 1004px)) 84vw, (min-width: 1005px) 80vw, 100vw" uri="nyt://image/dd9c6352-8667-5bf3-b542-7ac06d3d7f72" decoding="async" width="600" height="400"/></picture></div><figcaption data-testid="photoviewer-children-caption" class="css-1g9ic6e ewdxa0s0"><span class="css-jevhma e13ogyst0">Jaipur Golden Hospital in Delhi, where medical oxygen ran out, killing more than 20 people in a matter of hours.</span><span class="css-14fe1uy e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span><span aria-hidden="false">Atul Loke for The New York Times</span></span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-2"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">India is a major producer of compressed oxygen. But the Indian government moved too late to distribute supplies.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">State governments feuded over oxygen and seized tankers, creating bottlenecks and delays.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Delhi city officials didn’t build systems to produce or store oxygen and struggled to allocate dwindling supplies. When tight supplies and government missteps led oxygen to run out at Jaipur Golden, some families said the hospital offered no warning.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="Dropzone-5"></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-3"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Without a comprehensive coronavirus plan, <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/05/01/world/asia/india-covid19-modi.html" title="">Mr. Modi’s government</a> has left much of the burden to states, cities, hospitals and even individuals. The oxygen crisis tragically revealed the limits of a do-it-yourself approach.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">That approach will be tested again. Though infections have dropped, a vaccine shortage puts India at risk of a third wave. Without adequate preparations, the second wave’s tragedies could return.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“With an effective surge plan,” said Robert Matiru, a director at Unitaid, a health initiative affiliated with the World Health Organization, “this could have been averted.”</p><h2 class="css-13o6u42 eoo0vm40" id="link-53a428ce">A Crisis Brews</h2></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="ImageBlock-7"><div data-testid="imageblock-wrapper"><figure class="img-sz-large css-hxpw2c e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0" data-testid="photoviewer-children-figure"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-nwd8t8" data-testid="lazy-image"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:257.77777777777777px"></div></div></div><figcaption data-testid="photoviewer-children-caption" class="css-1g9ic6e ewdxa0s0"><span class="css-jevhma e13ogyst0">Receiving oxygen support at a place of worship in Delhi.</span><span class="css-14fe1uy e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span><span aria-hidden="false">Atul Loke for The New York Times</span></span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-4"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Anuradha Bansal had a 102-degree fever when she checked into Jaipur Golden on April 13. A veteran schoolteacher, Ms. Bansal had tested positive for Covid-19, along with her husband, Atul, and their two daughters.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="Dropzone-9"></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-5"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Jaipur Golden had a good reputation. A four-story private hospital, it offered specialties like orthopedics and pediatric gastroenterology. Its motto was “We Care … With Care.”</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">But Ms. Bansal was shocked by the crowds filling Jaipur Golden and other hospitals in Delhi. Sick people packed the reception area, some leaning against the walls. In her Covid-19 ward, she said, extra beds had been squeezed in.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Her husband, Atul, a lawyer, was lying on his back in the I.C.U. down the hall, a plastic oxygen mask strapped to his face. He had been healthy for his 54 years, a strong swimmer who could hold his breath for minutes and ate a wholesome diet of beans, whole grain flour and yogurt.</p><div data-testid="imageblock-wrapper"><figure class="img-sz-small css-nss59b e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-zgakxe erfvjey0" data-testid="photoviewer-children-figure"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-nwd8t8" data-testid="lazy-image"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:257.1333333333334px"></div></div></div><figcaption data-testid="photoviewer-children-caption" class="css-13ytnnu ewdxa0s0"><span class="css-jevhma e13ogyst0">Atul Bansal</span><span class="css-14fe1uy e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span><span aria-hidden="false">Anuradha Bansal</span></span></span></figcaption></figure></div><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Across northern India, medical oxygen was running short as Covid-19 caseloads soared. In one month, Delhi’s daily count had jumped to 13,468 from 419. Delhi’s 650 hospitals and nursing homes were so deluged that they were shutting their gates, leaving people to die at the curb or in their cars.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="Dropzone-11"></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-6"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Though the tragic experiences of other places, <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/18/world/middleeast/egypt-hospital-oxygen-covid.html" title="">like Egypt</a>, showed what happens when oxygen runs out, India was still unprepared. It produces about 7,100 metric tons of liquid oxygen a day, mostly for industrial use. At the pandemic’s peak, India’s demand soared to 9,500 metric tons a day.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Worse, the oxygen was in the wrong place. Most was produced near steel plants in eastern India, hundreds of miles from hot spots like Delhi.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">In November, a parliamentary committee urged leaders “to ensure that the oxygen inventory is in place.” A plan was unveiled to eventually build more than 160 plants that pull oxygen from the atmosphere for hospital use. Hospitals expanded their oxygen storage capacity by one-third, <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.pib.gov.in/PressReleasePage.aspx?PRID=1685013" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">according to government figures</a>.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="ImageBlock-13"><div data-testid="imageblock-wrapper"><figure class="img-sz-large css-hxpw2c e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0" data-testid="photoviewer-children-figure"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-nwd8t8" data-testid="lazy-image"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:257.77777777777777px"></div></div></div><figcaption data-testid="photoviewer-children-caption" class="css-1g9ic6e ewdxa0s0"><span class="css-jevhma e13ogyst0">An oxygen plant under construction in May in Delhi.</span><span class="css-14fe1uy e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span><span aria-hidden="false">Atul Loke for The New York Times</span></span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-7"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">As the second wave surged, it was clear that the efforts weren’t enough. Only about <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://twitter.com/MoHFW_INDIA/status/1383651682270072846?s=20" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">one-fifth</a> of the oxygen plants had been built. The extra storage represented only a quarter of India’s emergency needs. Oxygen supplies were still concentrated in specific regions.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="Dropzone-15"></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-8"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">On April 15, the Modi government essentially nationalized India’s medical oxygen and dictated each state’s allotment. Air Force planes would airlift empty cryogenic tanker trucks to places like the Tata Steel plant in Odisha State, where they would be filled with liquid oxygen, put on special train cars and moved more than 1,000 miles to Delhi.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Still, much of the burden remained with the states. In an April 17 meeting, Dr. Harsh Vardhan, India’s health minister, urged 11 state health chiefs to “plan in advance” and increase medical infrastructure, including oxygenated beds, “to deal with any further surge in cases.”</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Delhi officials warned that the central government wasn’t giving them enough. The Modi government allocated about 350 metric tons of oxygen a day to the capital. Delhi needed twice that and, in court proceedings, accused the government of basing the city’s allocation on prepandemic needs. The central government cited desperate needs in other places.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">In the meantime, the crowds of sick people at the gates of Jaipur Golden and other hospitals were growing.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="Dropzone-17"></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-9"><div class="css-53u6y8"><h2 class="css-13o6u42 eoo0vm40" id="link-5a821a19">Scrambling for Supplies</h2></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="ImageBlock-19"><div data-testid="imageblock-wrapper"><figure class="img-sz-large css-hxpw2c e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0" data-testid="photoviewer-children-figure"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-nwd8t8" data-testid="lazy-image"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:257.77777777777777px"></div></div></div><figcaption data-testid="photoviewer-children-caption" class="css-1g9ic6e ewdxa0s0"><span class="css-jevhma e13ogyst0">Rohit Gupta with his mother and wife near his home in Delhi. His father, Satish Kumar Gupta, died after oxygen ran out at Jaipur Golden.</span><span class="css-14fe1uy e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span><span aria-hidden="false">Atul Loke for The New York Times</span></span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-10"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">By April 20, Jaipur Golden was overstretched and undersupplied.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“My father was seething from inside,” said Rohit Gupta, a sales manager in Delhi whose father, Satish Kumar Gupta, had been admitted to the I.C.U. in early April. The younger Mr. Gupta said his father soiled the bed because nobody helped him go to the bathroom.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Mr. Gupta said his father cried out, “Take me away from here.” The hospital declined to comment.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">As the national government doled out limited amounts of oxygen, officials in Delhi grew increasingly worried. Its hospitals had built only one small oxygen-generating plant because there had previously been little need, said Manish Sisodia, Delhi’s deputy chief minister. And Delhi could store only about one day’s worth of its pandemic needs at its hospitals and in a city-owned tank.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“The neighborhood supply has long been adequate,” Mr. Sisodia said. “The problem only came when the plants that were regularly supplying Delhi were asked to apportion some to other states.”</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">He appealed to the central government on Twitter, saying major hospitals had only enough for a few hours.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-cfo9c3" data-testid="lazy-load-wrapper-{"bottom":-500}"></div><div data-testid="Dropzone-22"></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-11"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">As supplies dwindled, Delhi’s oxygen was increasingly being <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/Delhi/haryana-govt-official-stopped-oxygen-supply-manish-sisodia/article34376741.ece" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">confiscated</a> by other states.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">On April 21, officials in Haryana State <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.ndtv.com/delhi-news/green-corridor-set-up-for-truck-carrying-medical-oxygen-to-delhi-hospital-in-rohini-2418757" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">stopped</a> a Delhi-bound tanker containing oxygen. Officials in Uttar Pradesh did the same. In Rajasthan, officials briefly seized several.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The reason was simple: People in other states were also dying from a lack of oxygen. “If we have any left over,” Anil Vij, Haryana’s health minister, said <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://in.news.yahoo.com/video/delhi-govt-looted-oxygen-tanker-093044634.html?guccounter=1" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">to local media</a>, “then we will give it.”</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="ImageBlock-24"><div data-testid="imageblock-wrapper"><figure class="img-sz-large css-hxpw2c e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0" data-testid="photoviewer-children-figure"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-nwd8t8" data-testid="lazy-image"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:257.77777777777777px"></div></div></div><figcaption data-testid="photoviewer-children-caption" class="css-1g9ic6e ewdxa0s0"><span class="css-jevhma e13ogyst0">Employees in the Delhi oxygen command center.</span><span class="css-14fe1uy e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span><span aria-hidden="false">Atul Loke for The New York Times</span></span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-12"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Delhi sent police officers to the Haryana border, and the tanker was allowed to proceed.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">That day, Delhi received only 178 metric tons of liquid oxygen — half of what the central government had allocated and about a quarter of what the city needed.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">A Delhi court ordered the central government to stop other states from interfering with oxygen shipments. Just to make sure, Delhi began sending police escorts with the oxygen tankers.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="Dropzone-26"></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-13"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">To fill the gaps, tankers were hastily imported from other countries, but some were incompatible with Indian oxygen tanks. Mr. Sisodia recalled his emergency response team Googling different solutions in one frenzied effort that went from 4 a.m. to 8 p.m.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">On April 21, Mr. Sisodia called V.K. Bidhuri, a manager in Delhi’s oxygen distribution office.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“Sir,” Mr. Bidhuri asked him, “will we be able to save the people tonight?”</p><h2 class="css-13o6u42 eoo0vm40" id="link-334b9841">Breakdown</h2></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="ImageBlock-28"><div data-testid="imageblock-wrapper"><figure class="img-sz-large css-hxpw2c e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0" data-testid="photoviewer-children-figure"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-nwd8t8" data-testid="lazy-image"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:257.77777777777777px"></div></div></div><figcaption data-testid="photoviewer-children-caption" class="css-1g9ic6e ewdxa0s0"><span class="css-jevhma e13ogyst0">Oxygen tankers at a depot in Delhi.</span><span class="css-14fe1uy e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span><span aria-hidden="false">Atul Loke for The New York Times</span></span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-14"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">On April 23, the central government sent Delhi 308 metric tons of oxygen, less than half of its need.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">At Jaipur Golden, all 250 beds were full. Outside the emergency room, patients slumped in wheelchairs waited to be admitted.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="Dropzone-30"></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-15"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Seema Awasthi, a school principal from north Delhi, was propped up on her I.C.U. bed, a ventilator feeding her lungs. At 8:45 a.m., she sent a text to her family: “I have to be fine soon. Trying to be strong.”</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">That same morning, Mr. Modi huddled with the chief ministers of India’s 10 hardest-hit states.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“We fear a big tragedy may happen due to the oxygen shortage and we will never be able to forgive ourselves,” Delhi’s chief minister, Arvind Kejriwal, told him on the video call.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Delhi had taken over the city’s oxygen distribution the day before, directing tankers according to need. Spreadsheets showed the supplies each hospital had left.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">In desperate moments, officials could dispatch two city-owned trucks with stopgap supplies, answering anguished Twitter messages, texts or calls from a doctor or a patient’s relative. Though the system would eventually be computerized, Mr. Bidhuri, the oxygen distribution official, initially used a wire-bound notebook.</p><div data-testid="imageblock-wrapper"><figure class="img-sz-small css-nss59b e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-zgakxe erfvjey0" data-testid="photoviewer-children-figure"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-nwd8t8" data-testid="lazy-image"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:258.05797101449275px"></div></div></div><figcaption data-testid="photoviewer-children-caption" class="css-13ytnnu ewdxa0s0"><span class="css-jevhma e13ogyst0">Seema Awasthi, right, who died at Jaipur Golden, with her family.</span><span class="css-14fe1uy e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span><span aria-hidden="false">Himanshu Gupta</span></span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="Dropzone-32"></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-16"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Jaipur Golden typically received its daily oxygen shipment by 5 p.m., said Dr. D.K. Baluja, its medical director. This time, though, the truck didn’t appear. At Inox, an oxygen supply company, nobody picked up the phone.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Contacted by The Times, Inox said it distributed oxygen “per government of Delhi’s instructions.” Delhi officials said they would supply records for April 23 but then did not.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">At 7 p.m., Dr. Baluja called Delhi’s oxygen command center. Officials said they had none.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Jaipur Golden was nearly out. But employees and families said they had not been told. Some family members said they would have sought canisters on Delhi’s streets had they known.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Around 7 p.m., Ms. Bansal was summoned to the I.C.U. Her husband, Atul, had suffered a heart attack. The oxygen levels on his ventilator were fluctuating. He was writhing in his bed, gasping for air.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“I couldn’t bear to watch,” she said. She left.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">At 9:45 p.m., ventilator alarms rang across the I.C.U. The oxygen was gone.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="Dropzone-34"></div><div data-testid="ImageBlock-35"><div data-testid="imageblock-wrapper"><figure class="img-sz-large css-hxpw2c e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0" data-testid="photoviewer-children-figure"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-nwd8t8" data-testid="lazy-image"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:257.77777777777777px"></div></div></div><figcaption data-testid="photoviewer-children-caption" class="css-1g9ic6e ewdxa0s0"><span class="css-jevhma e13ogyst0">Manish Sisodia, Delhi’s deputy chief minister.</span><span class="css-14fe1uy e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span><span aria-hidden="false">Atul Loke for The New York Times</span></span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-17"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Dr. Baluja later said that Jaipur Golden had a backup system of 50 oxygen cylinders. That ran out, too, <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HL0ydd7bMjE" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">he said</a>.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">At 10:28 p.m., Ruchika Gupta telephoned from Amsterdam to check on her father, Satish Kumar Gupta. Right after the phone was answered, the receiver was put down.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“Hello? Hello?” Ms. Gupta asked.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">No response.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">In the background, she could hear the ding-ding of the ventilator alarms and someone muttering “Hari Om, Hari Om, Hari Om,” invoking God.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“My father was probably dying at that moment,” Ms. Gupta said.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Rohit Gupta, her brother, arrived at Jaipur Golden around 11:30 p.m. It was chaos, he said. People dashed in carrying oxygen cylinders. Distraught relatives threatened to kill doctors. One man paced around shouting: “I will not leave these doctors alone if something happens to my mother!”</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="Dropzone-37"></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-18"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Two tankers arrived close to midnight: a large one from Inox, seven hours late, and a smaller one from the Delhi government.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">For 21 patients — Atul Bansal, Satish Kumar Gupta, Seema Awasthi, Atul Kapoor, Raj Kumar Gupta, Gurinder Singh, Parvinder Singh, Delphin Massey, Manohar Lal and 12 others — it was too late.</p><h2 class="css-13o6u42 eoo0vm40" id="link-eddaf83">Aftermath</h2></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="ImageBlock-39"><div data-testid="imageblock-wrapper"><figure class="img-sz-large css-hxpw2c e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0" data-testid="photoviewer-children-figure"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-nwd8t8" data-testid="lazy-image"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:257.77777777777777px"></div></div></div><figcaption data-testid="photoviewer-children-caption" class="css-1g9ic6e ewdxa0s0"><span class="css-jevhma e13ogyst0">A makeshift care facility for Covid patients in Delhi in late April.</span><span class="css-14fe1uy e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span><span aria-hidden="false">Atul Loke for The New York Times</span></span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-19"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The next morning, Dr. Baluja appeared on television, weeping.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“They were my patients. They were my responsibility. They came on the faith of Dr. Baluja to Jaipur Golden Hospital,” he said. “And where did I put my faith? The government of India. Delhi government.”</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The next week, a Delhi government committee formed to look into the deaths cited the “natural virulent course of the disease” and concluded that “shortage of oxygen as the cause of death could not be ascertained.”</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="Dropzone-41"></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-20"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Mr. Sisodia acknowledged that “we should have done better and we should have done more,” but said that his team had saved thousands of lives. Jaipur Golden, now facing a lawsuit from several families, declined to comment further.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Many of the families blame national, local and hospital officials for the deaths. Several are demanding a criminal investigation.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Ms. Bansal keeps a portrait of her husband by her bedside.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Every day she lights an incense stick by it.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“I miss him at every living moment,” she said. “They killed him.”</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="ImageBlock-43"><div data-testid="imageblock-wrapper"><figure class="img-sz-large css-hxpw2c e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0" data-testid="photoviewer-children-figure"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-nwd8t8" data-testid="lazy-image"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:257.77777777777777px"></div></div></div><figcaption data-testid="photoviewer-children-caption" class="css-1g9ic6e ewdxa0s0"><span class="css-jevhma e13ogyst0">Refilling oxygen cylinders in Delhi in May.</span><span class="css-14fe1uy e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span><span aria-hidden="false">Atul Loke for The New York Times</span></span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div><div data-testid="RelatedLinksBlock-44"><div data-testid="lazy-loader"></div></div></section><div class="bottom-of-article"><div class="css-1i6tsou"><div class="css-h77nca eqi4ubu0"><div class="css-kzd6pg"><p>Jeffrey Gettleman is an international correspondent and a winner of the Pulitzer Prize. The extra storage represented only a quarter of India’s emergency needs. Oxygen supplies were still concentrated in specific regions."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":true,"adsDesktopHoldout":true,"adsHybrid":false,"adsMobile":true,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":23},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"On April 15, the Modi government essentially nationalized India’s medical oxygen and dictated each state’s allotment. Air Force planes would airlift empty cryogenic tanker trucks to places like the Tata Steel plant in Odisha State, where they would be filled with liquid oxygen, put on special train cars and moved more than 1,000 miles to Delhi."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":24},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Still, much of the burden remained with the states. In an April 17 meeting, Dr. Harsh Vardhan, India’s health minister, urged 11 state health chiefs to “plan in advance” and increase medical infrastructure, including oxygenated beds, “to deal with any further surge in cases.”"}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":25},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Delhi officials warned that the central government wasn’t giving them enough. The Modi government allocated about 350 metric tons of oxygen a day to the capital. Delhi needed twice that and, in court proceedings, accused the government of basing the city’s allocation on prepandemic needs. The central government cited desperate needs in other places."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":true,"bad":false,"index":26},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"In the meantime, the crowds of sick people at the gates of Jaipur Golden and other hospitals were growing."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":true,"adsHybrid":false,"adsMobile":true,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":27},{"__typename":"Heading2Block","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Scrambling for Supplies"}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"ImageBlock","media":{"__typename":"Image","altText":"","caption":{"__typename":"TextOnlyDocumentBlock","content":[{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Rohit Gupta with his mother and wife near his home in Delhi. The younger Mr. Gupta said his father soiled the bed because nobody helped him go to the bathroom."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":true,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":29},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Mr. Gupta said his father cried out, “Take me away from here.” The hospital declined to comment."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"As the national government doled out limited amounts of oxygen, officials in Delhi grew increasingly worried. And Delhi could store only about one day’s worth of its pandemic needs at its hospitals and in a city-owned tank."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":true,"bad":false,"index":30},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"“The states.”"}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsMobile":true,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":31},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"He Trying to be strong.”"}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":44},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"That same morning, Mr. Modi huddled with the chief ministers of India’s 10 hardest-hit states."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"“We fear a big tragedy may happen due to the oxygen shortage and we will never be able to forgive ourselves,” Delhi’s chief minister, Arvind Kejriwal, told him on the video call."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":45},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Delhi had taken over the city’s oxygen distribution the day before, directing tankers according to need. Spreadsheets showed the supplies each hospital had left."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":true,"bad":false,"index":46},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"In desperate moments, officials could dispatch two city-owned trucks with stopgap supplies, answering anguished Twitter messages, texts or calls from a doctor or a patient’s relative. Though the system would eventually be computerized, Mr. Bidhuri, the oxygen distribution official, initially used a wire-bound notebook."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsMobile":true,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":true,"index":47},{"__typename":"ImageBlock","media":{"__typename":"Image","altText":"","caption":{"__typename":"TextOnlyDocumentBlock","content":[{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Seema At Inox, an oxygen supply company, nobody picked up the phone."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":49},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Contacted by The Times, Inox said it distributed oxygen “per government of Delhi’s instructions.” Delhi officials said they would supply records for April 23 but then did not."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":true,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":true,"bad":false,"index":50},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"At 7 p.m., Dr. Baluja called Delhi’s oxygen command center. But employees and families said they had not been told. Some family members said they would have sought canisters on Delhi’s streets had they known."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsMobile":true,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":51},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Around 7 p.m., Ms. Bansal was summoned to the I.C.U. Her husband, Atul, had suffered a heart attack. The oxygen levels on his ventilator were fluctuating. He was writhing in his bed, gasping for air."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":52},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"“I couldn’t bear to watch,” she said. She left."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"At 9:45 p.m., ventilator alarms rang across the I.C.U. Right after the phone was answered, the receiver was put down."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":56},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"“Hello? mother!”"}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":true,"adsHybrid":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":true,"bad":false,"index":58},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Two oembed.title: The Night the Oxygen Ran Out (Published 2021)
oembed.summary: A cascading series of failures, from the central government on down, left hospitals across India without medical oxygen, killing hundreds. One tragic night in Delhi shows how it happened.
oembed.author_name: By Jeffrey Gettleman, Emily Schmall, Suhasini Raj and Hari Kumar
oembed.html: <iframe src="https://www.nytimes.com/svc/oembed/html/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F2021%2F06%2F28%2Fworld%2Fasia%2Findia-coronavirus-oxygen.html" scrolling="no" frameborder="0" allowtransparency="true" title="The Night the Oxygen Ran Out" style="border:none;max-width:500px;min-width:300px;min-height:550px;display:block;width:100%;"></iframe>
oembed.thumbnail_credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times

readabilityObject.title: How India's Covid-Hit Hospitals Ran Out of Oxygen
readabilityObject.content:
The Night the Oxygen Ran Out

A cascading series of failures, from the central government on down, left hospitals across India without medical oxygen, killing hundreds. One tragic night in Delhi shows how it happened.

Workers refilling oxygen cylinders at a factory in Delhi in early May.Credit...Atul Loke for The New York Times

  • June 28, 2021

NEW DELHI — At 9:45 p.m., alarms blared across the intensive care unit of Jaipur Golden Hospital. Over two dozen patients on ventilators couldn’t breathe. Some flailed their arms and legs. Others cried for help, choking sounds coming from their throats as if they were being strangled.

Mechanics sprinted to the maintenance room to see what was wrong. Nurses grabbed small plastic pumps to fill the lungs of critically ill patients by hand.

It wasn’t enough. Jaipur Golden, a respected hospital in Delhi, had run out of medical oxygen. Over the next seven hours, 21 coronavirus patients died.

“Nobody can forget that night,” said Shaista Nigar, the hospital’s nursing superintendent. “It was a total breakdown.”

India is a major producer of compressed oxygen. But the Indian government moved too late to distribute supplies.

State governments feuded over oxygen and seized tankers, creating bottlenecks and delays.

Delhi city officials didn’t build systems to produce or store oxygen and struggled to allocate dwindling supplies. When tight supplies and government missteps led oxygen to run out at Jaipur Golden, some families said the hospital offered no warning.

Without a comprehensive coronavirus plan, Mr. Modi’s government has left much of the burden to states, cities, hospitals and even individuals. The oxygen crisis tragically revealed the limits of a do-it-yourself approach.

That approach will be tested again. Though infections have dropped, a vaccine shortage puts India at risk of a third wave. Without adequate preparations, the second wave’s tragedies could return.

“With an effective surge plan,” said Robert Matiru, a director at Unitaid, a health initiative affiliated with the World Health Organization, “this could have been averted.”

A Crisis Brews

Anuradha Bansal had a 102-degree fever when she checked into Jaipur Golden on April 13. A veteran schoolteacher, Ms. Bansal had tested positive for Covid-19, along with her husband, Atul, and their two daughters.

Jaipur Golden had a good reputation. A four-story private hospital, it offered specialties like orthopedics and pediatric gastroenterology. Its motto was “We Care … With Care.”

But Ms. Bansal was shocked by the crowds filling Jaipur Golden and other hospitals in Delhi. Sick people packed the reception area, some leaning against the walls. In her Covid-19 ward, she said, extra beds had been squeezed in.

Her husband, Atul, a lawyer, was lying on his back in the I.C.U. down the hall, a plastic oxygen mask strapped to his face. He had been healthy for his 54 years, a strong swimmer who could hold his breath for minutes and ate a wholesome diet of beans, whole grain flour and yogurt.

Across northern India, medical oxygen was running short as Covid-19 caseloads soared. In one month, Delhi’s daily count had jumped to 13,468 from 419. Delhi’s 650 hospitals and nursing homes were so deluged that they were shutting their gates, leaving people to die at the curb or in their cars.

Though the tragic experiences of other places, like Egypt, showed what happens when oxygen runs out, India was still unprepared. It produces about 7,100 metric tons of liquid oxygen a day, mostly for industrial use. At the pandemic’s peak, India’s demand soared to 9,500 metric tons a day.

Worse, the oxygen was in the wrong place. Most was produced near steel plants in eastern India, hundreds of miles from hot spots like Delhi.

In November, a parliamentary committee urged leaders “to ensure that the oxygen inventory is in place.” A plan was unveiled to eventually build more than 160 plants that pull oxygen from the atmosphere for hospital use. Hospitals expanded their oxygen storage capacity by one-third, according to government figures.

As the second wave surged, it was clear that the efforts weren’t enough. Only about one-fifth of the oxygen plants had been built. The extra storage represented only a quarter of India’s emergency needs. Oxygen supplies were still concentrated in specific regions.

On April 15, the Modi government essentially nationalized India’s medical oxygen and dictated each state’s allotment. Air Force planes would airlift empty cryogenic tanker trucks to places like the Tata Steel plant in Odisha State, where they would be filled with liquid oxygen, put on special train cars and moved more than 1,000 miles to Delhi.

Still, much of the burden remained with the states. In an April 17 meeting, Dr. Harsh Vardhan, India’s health minister, urged 11 state health chiefs to “plan in advance” and increase medical infrastructure, including oxygenated beds, “to deal with any further surge in cases.”

Delhi officials warned that the central government wasn’t giving them enough. The Modi government allocated about 350 metric tons of oxygen a day to the capital. Delhi needed twice that and, in court proceedings, accused the government of basing the city’s allocation on prepandemic needs. The central government cited desperate needs in other places.

In the meantime, the crowds of sick people at the gates of Jaipur Golden and other hospitals were growing.

Scrambling for Supplies

By April 20, Jaipur Golden was overstretched and undersupplied.

“My father was seething from inside,” said Rohit Gupta, a sales manager in Delhi whose father, Satish Kumar Gupta, had been admitted to the I.C.U. in early April. The younger Mr. Gupta said his father soiled the bed because nobody helped him go to the bathroom.

Mr. Gupta said his father cried out, “Take me away from here.” The hospital declined to comment.

As the national government doled out limited amounts of oxygen, officials in Delhi grew increasingly worried. Its hospitals had built only one small oxygen-generating plant because there had previously been little need, said Manish Sisodia, Delhi’s deputy chief minister. And Delhi could store only about one day’s worth of its pandemic needs at its hospitals and in a city-owned tank.

“The neighborhood supply has long been adequate,” Mr. Sisodia said. “The problem only came when the plants that were regularly supplying Delhi were asked to apportion some to other states.”

He appealed to the central government on Twitter, saying major hospitals had only enough for a few hours.

As supplies dwindled, Delhi’s oxygen was increasingly being confiscated by other states.

On April 21, officials in Haryana State stopped a Delhi-bound tanker containing oxygen. Officials in Uttar Pradesh did the same. In Rajasthan, officials briefly seized several.

The reason was simple: People in other states were also dying from a lack of oxygen. “If we have any left over,” Anil Vij, Haryana’s health minister, said to local media, “then we will give it.”

Delhi sent police officers to the Haryana border, and the tanker was allowed to proceed.

That day, Delhi received only 178 metric tons of liquid oxygen — half of what the central government had allocated and about a quarter of what the city needed.

A Delhi court ordered the central government to stop other states from interfering with oxygen shipments. Just to make sure, Delhi began sending police escorts with the oxygen tankers.

To fill the gaps, tankers were hastily imported from other countries, but some were incompatible with Indian oxygen tanks. Mr. Sisodia recalled his emergency response team Googling different solutions in one frenzied effort that went from 4 a.m. to 8 p.m.

On April 21, Mr. Sisodia called V.K. Bidhuri, a manager in Delhi’s oxygen distribution office.

“Sir,” Mr. Bidhuri asked him, “will we be able to save the people tonight?”

Breakdown

On April 23, the central government sent Delhi 308 metric tons of oxygen, less than half of its need.

At Jaipur Golden, all 250 beds were full. Outside the emergency room, patients slumped in wheelchairs waited to be admitted.

Seema Awasthi, a school principal from north Delhi, was propped up on her I.C.U. bed, a ventilator feeding her lungs. At 8:45 a.m., she sent a text to her family: “I have to be fine soon. Trying to be strong.”

That same morning, Mr. Modi huddled with the chief ministers of India’s 10 hardest-hit states.

“We fear a big tragedy may happen due to the oxygen shortage and we will never be able to forgive ourselves,” Delhi’s chief minister, Arvind Kejriwal, told him on the video call.

Delhi had taken over the city’s oxygen distribution the day before, directing tankers according to need. Spreadsheets showed the supplies each hospital had left.

In desperate moments, officials could dispatch two city-owned trucks with stopgap supplies, answering anguished Twitter messages, texts or calls from a doctor or a patient’s relative. Though the system would eventually be computerized, Mr. Bidhuri, the oxygen distribution official, initially used a wire-bound notebook.

Jaipur Golden typically received its daily oxygen shipment by 5 p.m., said Dr. D.K. Baluja, its medical director. This time, though, the truck didn’t appear. At Inox, an oxygen supply company, nobody picked up the phone.

Contacted by The Times, Inox said it distributed oxygen “per government of Delhi’s instructions.” Delhi officials said they would supply records for April 23 but then did not.

At 7 p.m., Dr. Baluja called Delhi’s oxygen command center. Officials said they had none.

Jaipur Golden was nearly out. But employees and families said they had not been told. Some family members said they would have sought canisters on Delhi’s streets had they known.

Around 7 p.m., Ms. Bansal was summoned to the I.C.U. Her husband, Atul, had suffered a heart attack. The oxygen levels on his ventilator were fluctuating. He was writhing in his bed, gasping for air.

“I couldn’t bear to watch,” she said. She left.

At 9:45 p.m., ventilator alarms rang across the I.C.U. The oxygen was gone.

Dr. Baluja later said that Jaipur Golden had a backup system of 50 oxygen cylinders. That ran out, too, he said.

At 10:28 p.m., Ruchika Gupta telephoned from Amsterdam to check on her father, Satish Kumar Gupta. Right after the phone was answered, the receiver was put down.

“Hello? Hello?” Ms. Gupta asked.

No response.

In the background, she could hear the ding-ding of the ventilator alarms and someone muttering “Hari Om, Hari Om, Hari Om,” invoking God.

“My father was probably dying at that moment,” Ms. Gupta said.

Rohit Gupta, her brother, arrived at Jaipur Golden around 11:30 p.m. It was chaos, he said. People dashed in carrying oxygen cylinders. Distraught relatives threatened to kill doctors. One man paced around shouting: “I will not leave these doctors alone if something happens to my mother!”

Two tankers arrived close to midnight: a large one from Inox, seven hours late, and a smaller one from the Delhi government.

For 21 patients — Atul Bansal, Satish Kumar Gupta, Seema Awasthi, Atul Kapoor, Raj Kumar Gupta, Gurinder Singh, Parvinder Singh, Delphin Massey, Manohar Lal and 12 others — it was too late.

Aftermath

The next morning, Dr. Baluja appeared on television, weeping.

“They were my patients. They were my responsibility. They came on the faith of Dr. Baluja to Jaipur Golden Hospital,” he said. “And where did I put my faith? The government of India. Delhi government.”

The next week, a Delhi government committee formed to look into the deaths cited the “natural virulent course of the disease” and concluded that “shortage of oxygen as the cause of death could not be ascertained.”

Mr. Sisodia acknowledged that “we should have done better and we should have done more,” but said that his team had saved thousands of lives. Jaipur Golden, now facing a lawsuit from several families, declined to comment further.

Many of the families blame national, local and hospital officials for the deaths. Several are demanding a criminal investigation.

Ms. Bansal keeps a portrait of her husband by her bedside.

Every day she lights an incense stick by it.

“I miss him at every living moment,” she said. “They killed him.”

Suhasini Raj has worked for over a decade as an investigative journalist with Indian and international news outlets. Based in the New Delhi bureau, she joined The Times in 2014. More about Suhasini Raj

Hari Kumar covers India, based out of New Delhi. He has been a journalist for more than two decades. More about Hari Kumar

One tragic night in Delhi shows how it happened.Workers refilling oxygen cylinders at a factory in Delhi in early May.Credit...Atul Loke for The New York TimesJune 28, 2021NEW DELHI — At 9:45 p.m., alarms blared across the intensive care unit of Jaipur Golden Hospital. Over two dozen patients on ventilators couldn’t breathe. Some flailed their arms and legs. Others cried for help, choking sounds coming from their throats as if they were being strangled.Mechanics sprinted to the maintenance room to see what was wrong. Nurses grabbed small plastic pumps to fill the lungs of critically ill patients by hand.It wasn’t enough. Jaipur Golden, a respected hospital in Delhi, had run out of medical oxygen. Over the next seven hours, 21 coronavirus patients died.“Nobody can forget that night,” said Shaista Nigar, the hospital’s nursing superintendent. “It was a total breakdown.”ImageJaipur Golden Hospital in Delhi, where medical oxygen ran out, killing more than 20 people in a matter of hours.Credit...Atul Loke for The New York TimesIndia is a major producer of compressed oxygen. But the Indian government moved too late to distribute supplies.State governments feuded over oxygen and seized tankers, creating bottlenecks and delays.Delhi city officials didn’t build systems to produce or store oxygen and struggled to allocate dwindling supplies. When tight supplies and government missteps led oxygen to run out at Jaipur Golden, some families said the hospital offered no warning.Without a comprehensive coronavirus plan, Mr. Modi’s government has left much of the burden to states, cities, hospitals and even individuals. The oxygen crisis tragically revealed the limits of a do-it-yourself approach.That approach will be tested again. Though infections have dropped, a vaccine shortage puts India at risk of a third wave. Without adequate preparations, the second wave’s tragedies could return.“With an effective surge plan,” said Robert Matiru, a director at Unitaid, a health initiative affiliated with the World Health Organization, “this could have been averted.”A Crisis BrewsImageReceiving oxygen support at a place of worship in Delhi.Credit...Atul Loke for The New York TimesAnuradha Bansal had a 102-degree fever when she checked into Jaipur Golden on April 13. A veteran schoolteacher, Ms. Bansal had tested positive for Covid-19, along with her husband, Atul, and their two daughters.Jaipur Golden had a good reputation. A four-story private hospital, it offered specialties like orthopedics and pediatric gastroenterology. Its motto was “We Care … With Care.”But Ms. Bansal was shocked by the crowds filling Jaipur Golden and other hospitals in Delhi. Sick people packed the reception area, some leaning against the walls. In her Covid-19 ward, she said, extra beds had been squeezed in.Her husband, Atul, a lawyer, was lying on his back in the I.C.U. down the hall, a plastic oxygen mask strapped to his face. He had been healthy for his 54 years, a strong swimmer who could hold his breath for minutes and ate a wholesome diet of beans, whole grain flour and yogurt.ImageAtul BansalCredit...Anuradha BansalAcross northern India, medical oxygen was running short as Covid-19 caseloads soared. In one month, Delhi’s daily count had jumped to 13,468 from 419. Delhi’s 650 hospitals and nursing homes were so deluged that they were shutting their gates, leaving people to die at the curb or in their cars.Though the tragic experiences of other places, like Egypt, showed what happens when oxygen runs out, India was still unprepared. It produces about 7,100 metric tons of liquid oxygen a day, mostly for industrial use. At the pandemic’s peak, India’s demand soared to 9,500 metric tons a day.Worse, the oxygen was in the wrong place. Most was produced near steel plants in eastern India, hundreds of miles from hot spots like Delhi.In November, a parliamentary committee urged leaders “to ensure that the oxygen inventory is in place.” A plan was unveiled to eventually build more than 160 plants that pull oxygen from the atmosphere for hospital use. Hospitals expanded their oxygen storage capacity by one-third, according to government figures.ImageAn oxygen plant under construction in May in Delhi.Credit...Atul Loke for The New York TimesAs the second wave surged, it was clear that the efforts weren’t enough. Only about one-fifth of the oxygen plants had been built. The extra storage represented only a quarter of India’s emergency needs. Oxygen supplies were still concentrated in specific regions.On April 15, the Modi government essentially nationalized India’s medical oxygen and dictated each state’s allotment. Air Force planes would airlift empty cryogenic tanker trucks to places like the Tata Steel plant in Odisha State, where they would be filled with liquid oxygen, put on special train cars and moved more than 1,000 miles to Delhi.Still, much of the burden remained with the states. In an April 17 meeting, Dr. Harsh Vardhan, India’s health minister, urged 11 state health chiefs to “plan in advance” and increase medical infrastructure, including oxygenated beds, “to deal with any further surge in cases.”Delhi officials warned that the central government wasn’t giving them enough. The Modi government allocated about 350 metric tons of oxygen a day to the capital. Delhi needed twice that and, in court proceedings, accused the government of basing the city’s allocation on prepandemic needs. The central government cited desperate needs in other places.In the meantime, the crowds of sick people at the gates of Jaipur Golden and other hospitals were growing.Scrambling for SuppliesImageRohit Gupta with his mother and wife near his home in Delhi. His father, Satish Kumar Gupta, died after oxygen ran out at Jaipur Golden.Credit...Atul Loke for The New York TimesBy April 20, Jaipur Golden was overstretched and undersupplied.“My father was seething from inside,” said Rohit Gupta, a sales manager in Delhi whose father, Satish Kumar Gupta, had been admitted to the I.C.U. in early April. The younger Mr. Gupta said his father soiled the bed because nobody helped him go to the bathroom.Mr. Gupta said his father cried out, “Take me away from here.” The hospital declined to comment.As the national government doled out limited amounts of oxygen, officials in Delhi grew increasingly worried. Its hospitals had built only one small oxygen-generating plant because there had previously been little need, said Manish Sisodia, Delhi’s deputy chief minister. And Delhi could store only about one day’s worth of its pandemic needs at its hospitals and in a city-owned tank.“The neighborhood supply has long been adequate,” Mr. Sisodia said. “The problem only came when the plants that were regularly supplying Delhi were asked to apportion some to other states.”He appealed to the central government on Twitter, saying major hospitals had only enough for a few hours.As supplies dwindled, Delhi’s oxygen was increasingly being confiscated by other states.On April 21, officials in Haryana State stopped a Delhi-bound tanker containing oxygen. Officials in Uttar Pradesh did the same. In Rajasthan, officials briefly seized several.The reason was simple: People in other states were also dying from a lack of oxygen. “If we have any left over,” Anil Vij, Haryana’s health minister, said to local media, “then we will give it.”ImageEmployees in the Delhi oxygen command center.Credit...Atul Loke for The New York TimesDelhi sent police officers to the Haryana border, and the tanker was allowed to proceed.That day, Delhi received only 178 metric tons of liquid oxygen — half of what the central government had allocated and about a quarter of what the city needed.A Delhi court ordered the central government to stop other states from interfering with oxygen shipments. Just to make sure, Delhi began sending police escorts with the oxygen tankers.To fill the gaps, tankers were hastily imported from other countries, but some were incompatible with Indian oxygen tanks. Mr. Sisodia recalled his emergency response team Googling different solutions in one frenzied effort that went from 4 a.m. to 8 p.m.On April 21, Mr. Sisodia called V.K. Bidhuri, a manager in Delhi’s oxygen distribution office.“Sir,” Mr. Bidhuri asked him, “will we be able to save the people tonight?”BreakdownImageOxygen tankers at a depot in Delhi.Credit...Atul Loke for The New York TimesOn April 23, the central government sent Delhi 308 metric tons of oxygen, less than half of its need.At Jaipur Golden, all 250 beds were full. Outside the emergency room, patients slumped in wheelchairs waited to be admitted.Seema Awasthi, a school principal from north Delhi, was propped up on her I.C.U. bed, a ventilator feeding her lungs. At 8:45 a.m., she sent a text to her family: “I have to be fine soon. Trying to be strong.”That same morning, Mr. Modi huddled with the chief ministers of India’s 10 hardest-hit states.“We fear a big tragedy may happen due to the oxygen shortage and we will never be able to forgive ourselves,” Delhi’s chief minister, Arvind Kejriwal, told him on the video call.Delhi had taken over the city’s oxygen distribution the day before, directing tankers according to need. Spreadsheets showed the supplies each hospital had left.In desperate moments, officials could dispatch two city-owned trucks with stopgap supplies, answering anguished Twitter messages, texts or calls from a doctor or a patient’s relative. Though the system would eventually be computerized, Mr. Bidhuri, the oxygen distribution official, initially used a wire-bound notebook.ImageSeema Awasthi, right, who died at Jaipur Golden, with her family.Credit...Himanshu GuptaJaipur Golden typically received its daily oxygen shipment by 5 p.m., said Dr. D.K. Baluja, its medical director. This time, though, the truck didn’t appear. At Inox, an oxygen supply company, nobody picked up the phone.Contacted by The Times, Inox said it distributed oxygen “per government of Delhi’s instructions.” Delhi officials said they would supply records for April 23 but then did not.At 7 p.m., Dr. Baluja called Delhi’s oxygen command center. Some family members said they would have sought canisters on Delhi’s streets had they known.Around 7 p.m., Ms. Bansal was summoned to the I.C.U. Her husband, Atul, had suffered a heart attack. The oxygen levels on his ventilator were fluctuating. He was writhing in his bed, gasping for air.“I couldn’t bear to watch,” she said. She left.At 9:45 p.m., ventilator alarms rang across the I.C.U. The oxygen was gone.ImageManish Sisodia, Delhi’s deputy chief minister.Credit...Atul Loke for The New York TimesDr. Baluja later said that Jaipur Golden had a backup system of 50 oxygen cylinders. That ran out, too, he said.At 10:28 p.m., Ruchika Gupta telephoned from Amsterdam to check on her father, Satish Kumar Gupta. Right after the phone was answered, the receiver was put down.“Hello? Hello?” Ms. Gupta asked.No response.In the background, she could hear the ding-ding of the ventilator alarms and someone muttering “Hari Om, Hari Om, Hari Om,” invoking God.“My father was probably dying at that moment,” Ms. Gupta said.Rohit Gupta, her brother, arrived at Jaipur Golden around 11:30 p.m. It was chaos, he said. People dashed in carrying oxygen cylinders. Distraught relatives threatened to kill doctors. They were my responsibility. They came on the faith of Dr. Baluja to Jaipur Golden Hospital,” he said. “And where did I put my faith? The government of India. Delhi government.”The next week, a Delhi government committee formed to look into the deaths cited the “natural virulent course of the disease” and concluded that “shortage of oxygen as the cause of death could not be ascertained.”Mr. Sisodia acknowledged that “we should have done better and we should have done more,” but said that his team had saved thousands of lives. readabilityObject.excerpt: A cascading series of failures, from the central government on down, left hospitals across India without medical oxygen, killing hundreds. One tragic night in Delhi shows how it happened.
readabilityObject.byline: Jeffrey Gettleman, Emily Schmall, Suhasini Raj, Hari Kumar
